title: 114_hr194
content: The Act may be cited as the "Medgar Wiley Evers Congressional Gold Medal Act". Medgar Wiley Evers was born in 1925 in Mississippi, served in World War II, completed college, and married Myrlie Beasley. Medgar Evers worked in Bayou, Mississippi, established NAACP chapters, and applied to the University of Mississippi School of Law but was denied enrollment. He became the first Field Secretary for the Mississippi NAACP chapter, organizing voter registration efforts despite facing threats. Despite numerous threats against his life, Medgar Evers continued his work with dedication and courage, organizing rallies, building NAACP membership, and educating the public on Civil Rights. His efforts led to a lawsuit against the Jackson, Mississippi public school system, gaining national media attention as a Civil Rights leader. Evers was arrested, beaten, and jailed for his ongoing protests and advocacy for African-American rights in Mississippi. Medgar Evers, a Civil Rights leader, was violently shot and killed in front of his home on June 12, 1963. His murderer, Byron De La Beckwith, was arrested but acquitted in two trials in 1964. It wasn't until 1990 that De La Beckwith was finally convicted for Evers' murder. Evers, a veteran, was buried with full military honors at Arlington National Cemetery. In 1990, Mrs. Evers persuaded Mississippi prosecutors to reopen Medgar Evers' murder case, leading to the conviction and life imprisonment of his killer in 1994. Congress honored Medgar Evers posthumously with the Congressional Gold Medal for his work on racial equality, which played a significant role in the passage of the Civil Rights Act in 1964. SEC. 3. CONGRESSIONAL GOLD MEDAL. The Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate will arrange for the posthumous presentation of a gold medal to honor Medgar Wiley Evers for his contributions to racial equality. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal. Once awarded, the gold medal will be given to the Mississippi Civil Rights Museum for display or loan. The Secretary is authorized to produce and sell bronze duplicates of the gold medal at a price covering all costs. The medals are considered national medals and numismatic items under specific codes.
